author: {'steamid': '76561198019205444', 'num_games_owned': 4268, 'num_reviews': 323, 'playtime_forever': 157, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 157, 'last_played': 1392702249}
review:
I was sold from the video, it looks great. Minecraft with guns and a grappling hook! Like Just Cause 2 in Minecraft. What's not to love?

It is like Minecraft with guns made in Java. Before the developer was done with this game, he was already hyping up the sequil. This is great for a first time developer. It is a simple Minecraft with guns. The guns work well enough, the enemies are giant and easy to hit. When you die, that's it. You crash back to the launcher. Speaking of the launcher, that's the only way to adjust the settings. Including controls. This is probably the 2nd worst button configuration I've ever seen. You select what the key does, then you find the key from a drop down list. When you set a key, chances are it unsets another key that has nothing to do with the key you just set. Such as if I set something to use the 'Right Key' then I set something to the 'Enter Key' it will set the previous 'Right Key' to the 'F2 Key.' Huh? Again, this is clearly someone's first game.

With all that being said, the game generates a random world and yet always starts you suspended high above the ground in orbit, suspended. When you find out the gravity button to drop you from the sky you might die on impact. It is quite unforgiving. If you survive the fall through the use of the gravity button, you're immediately in hostile territory. Sometimes the floating red monsters will murder you before you even land. From the start, the guns are underpowered. When you run out of ammo, you start losing health when you shoot. An understanding of enemy levels would have been nice, such as a beginner enemy should take one or two bullets. Then as you progress they take more bullets and then you find better guns or upgrade so they take less bullets.

The only redeeming factor about this game is multi-player, but really, if you're playing with friends any game will be fun, because you and your friends will always have fun. That's why they're your friends.

There are far better FPS games, which this is a FPS. I can't even call it Minecraft, since there's not much crafting or world craftability as there is with Minecraft. I just can't recommend this game. It is also very telling when a game took so long to be Greenlit.
developer_response:
Thank you for taking the time to write a review, even though it is critical. However, I do want to fill in some readers:

1) When you die, you shouldn't "crash back to the launcher". I'm not sure if something is crashing on your end, but when you die, you should see a "Press any key to respawn" message. You'll respawn close to where you died with most of your character intact and not be brought back to the launcher.

2) You start in the air because you were approaching the planet & this is where the story starts. You can fall to your death if you disable your jetpack, but you can also turn your jetpack back on right before you hit the ground to survive. Keep in mind this is a "trick" to bypass the Demons (which is the "standard" start of the game). The "trick" is explained in the guide video.

3) 3079 isn't easy & I admit it has a learning curve. The starting enemies were not designed to only take one or two bullets. However, you start in a friendly zone (once you reach the ground), so you should have time to improve your character before meeting you first enemies.

4) When you "run out of ammo", you are running out of energy which powers your life support systems. However, this isn't necessarily a bad thing since your Energy stat will increase to accommodate.

I'm also glad you can't call it Minecraft, because 3079 wasn't designed to be a "Minecraft" clone, although it does have some building features. Saying 3079 is a "simple Minecraft with guns" game is selling it a bit short, since 3079 was designed to be an action RPG with randomly generated items, quests, stats, story & skills to improve on. Guncraft is much better described as a "Minecraft with guns" game than 3079 is, in my opinion.

Anyway, good luck finding a game you enjoy!

Don't get me wrong, i never really cared about negative things, since they aren't as bad in this game, i felt it just didn't have anything really positive. Its a mediocore game that was slightly dull and a few strange decisions within the art style and gameplay. I felt everything was very clunky and nothing was exciting to see or do. I found the building capture missions quite clever and the stealth system doesn't exactly suck, just as said before, not to exciting.

I hope in the future the developers learn from their mistakes and make something more fun. I felt they tried to keep everyone happy and doing so dulling out their game. As a famous quote is said "You can please all of the people some of the time and some of the people all of the time, but you can't please all of the people all of the time."

Weird and a bit unpolished, but surprisingly fun. Quite short though - only took me 5 hours to complete.

This game may look like Minecraft, but there's actually no crafting and mining is an optional extra. The core of this game is fighting your way through a randomly generated world, doing random quests, improving your stats and getting better items. 

Yes, this sounds like every other randomly generated game out there, but 3079 is novel enough and short enough that you won't get bored of it.

review: I founf 3079 to be more of an exercise in frustration than an RPG. The idea is interesting. The system seems well thought out. Yet, the insane difficulty is a complete turnoff for me. 2 hours of trial and error and I finally got to the surface with all my gear (which I don't think was supposed to happen). But that's okay because it still didn't matter. It didn't matter which quest I took, I inevitately failed miserably, each death resulted in one less item and soon I was essentially defenseless. The final straw was a mission to sneek out and retrieve something without being seen. So I turned on my camoflauge (slow movement) and crept to the area. As far as I could tell there was nothing nearby it should be a cakewalk. I ended being blown up by ??? I don't know there was nothing there! I wasn't spotted (which would have ended the mission) before hand, I was just dead. But of course death ended the mission. This follows a series of equally inane and frustrating mishaps where I found myself slaughtered and useless over and over and over again. If I wanted insane difficulty I would play a rouge-like, but even then there is a sense of progress - not here.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022336820', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 249, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 249, 'last_played': 1389118913}
review:
Just bought the game on Steam and holy damn does it look good. Not only does the world feel organic and full of dangers, but there's solid gameplay utilizing the best parts of both the building of Minecraft and item-searching in dungeon-diving of rogue-likes.

Also, it looks good 'n artsy. None of that Minecraft monotone but rather some creepy and original style to it. Randmization really makes stuff interesting in this game. There's definitely lots to see, meet and explore.

As to the difficulty, it's the game's strong point. This world is relentless and does need you to take it seriously. You need to acquire skill first, then items in order to survive and advance in progress-indicating levels and power.

But what I'm really looking forward to is what's in the future of the game. It does seem it could easily get some servers with communities similar to those of DayZ in order to make the game feel even more organic, purposeful and alive. Not to mention patches and mods.

It's a world ever at war. And you need to shape it.

review:
This game, while an excellent idea, fails in its delivery. While playing I found myself consistently frustrated at tasks that were nearly impossible to complete (due to the fact that everything, missions and terrain, are procedurally generated). The controls are fairly hard to get used to (especially in the aircraft), and the only tutorial is a screen with control mappings. Because the game is significantly different than most other games out there, a fully realized tutorial would be immensely helpful.

While there were parts of the game I really enjoyed, I thought some serious polish was still needed to be playable in the long term. I will certainly try out the sequel (3089) and see if they've polished these issues, as the concept is quite excellent.
developer_response:
The difficulty does range quite a bit, which some players like as variety, while others will struggle with. There is a rather complete guide in the "Guides" section, which should be helpful.

The aircraft is free to hop in & use, so to balance them, I made them a bit harder to control.

Anyway, I do hope you check out 3089. There have been lots of changes to how 3089 works & I hope you will enjoy it!

author: {'steamid': '76561197983216084', 'num_games_owned': 326, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 167, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 167, 'last_played': 1408574207}
review:
Напоминает Minecraft лишь отдалённо своим кубизмом и возможностью установки собственных кубов.

Возможности песочницы сильно урезаны: вы можете ставить весьма ограниченное число видов блоков (причём, их количество зависит от объёма вашего кошелька), буром много не накопаешь (копать можно лишь считанные виды блоков; единственный бонус раскопок - редкие уровневые драгоценные камни). Крафт отсутствует.

Но зато - весьма приятный шутер с элементами RPG. Случайно генерируемый мир, задания (всего несколько типов, но награды - всегда разные и зависят от уровня локации) и проблемы на вашу шею. А также: возможность прокачки различных характеристик и навыков игрока, поиск более мощного оружия и надёжной экипировки (путём торговли, воровства или убийства), захват шустрых вооружённых истребителей.
Сюжет. Да, он есть. С завязкой, развитием и завершением. После конца сюжета игра закончится.

Особый бонус: кроме возможности совместной игры (ну или PvP) игра является кроссплатформенной (Win, Mac, Lin).

Чего ещё для счастья надо? )

review:
I wasn't sure how this one was gonna go:  it is either a tentative recommend or a just barely, spend a paragraph trying to sell you on the game anyway, ...unrecommend.   Ultimately, there is enough of a cool game here for me to keep putting time into it.

The games name is strange, don't worry about it.  Here's what jumps out:  Action RPG.  The game is an FPS action rpg.  It looks like an ASCII Minecraft, but has all the ARPG symptoms.

XP grind?  GODDAMN RIGHT SON.  Your skills increase as you use them.  Pick some pockets dawg, raise that stat.

Loot? Yo, the big guy over there wielding a sword with fangs that one shotted the NPC from your faction?  You take his life, you take his blade.

"... But clizzy, this dudes sword SUCKS BALLS dewd!"  Yeah, it happens.  But you can sell that piece in almost any area.  Items scale with the enemies, who scale with the zone.  You're in a level 9 zone, the level 9 enemies drop level 9 shit that usually be sellin' for a pretty penny even when they are booty butter.  This is awesome because....

There's mad cool shit to loot in this game!  This is my favorite part:  your character can equip jet packs and grappling hooks that give you crazzzzzzzzy mobility.  You can fly into sky fortresses, or zip around the landscape with non-stop grapple shots.  Thing is, though, these bitches also scale.  Level 1 hooks/packs can be used when holding 40 weight, no more.  Every level adds an additional 40 lbs.   It's cool zipping into a high level zone, on a mad hunt for the shopkeeper or drop zone with the clutch twink grappling hook/jet pack.  You have to get out alive too, because when you die you lose an item.  The game is sadistic, it will eliminate the item you hold most dear.

I suppose I wish the game felt more complete.  I've put some goodly time into it and I'm not sure if there is anything else to do but loot grind.  The building mechanic?  No idea what's going on there.  Completely arbitrary, in my experience.

However, I have to say that I haven't got many quests done in the *main* story line.  There's a little bit of RNG involved with quest givers having to give you a specific reward to advance - it can get a little frustrating.   Hunting for the right people always devolved into loot grinding and murdering things.  This was really fun for a bit, and I'll probably sit down a few more times to see just deep the game goes, but it becomes nothing more than pure carrot-sticking.   Still hours of fun.

6.9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197971913841', 'num_games_owned': 710, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 67, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 67, 'last_played': 1385425462}
review:
I would call ‘3079 – Block Action RPG,’ a ‘cult-classic’ even though it’s still fairly new.  The reason I say that is because I feel that you’re either going to love this game or hate it.  Personally, I could not get into it.  I restarted the game about 12 different times, each time seeing if I had ‘missed’ something or simply didn’t understand the concept.  However, even after 12 times, I continued to scratch my head – wondering about the many facets of this game.

I really loved the music, it does a great job driving-home the ‘futuristic’ vibe of the game.  I also love the ‘mechanics’ to the game.  You progressively get better at skills in the game by doing them – don’t like your terrible aim with that rifle, then keep shooting at things (all the things!).  I also noticed that the game included skills such as ‘mining’ and ‘stealing,’ which is awesome!

Though, I believe what ruined this game for me was the story and setting; I think that’s what made me restart the game so times, too.  The, seemingly, inconsistent size of the NPCs, the strange location of buildings (yes, I realize it’s a randomly generated world, but there needs to be some consistency for an RPG), and the way items are distributed to the player (randomly generated on the ground, just sitting there or sold by a vendor – very inconsistent).  I tried to discover the reason, but it didn’t appear to be laid out anywhere obvious to the player, no in-game ‘books’ to discover with clues, no conversation with NPCs to help get answers.  The world needs to be 'plausible,' (not to be confused with possible) and the developer has not achieved that.

I feel that a video game has the same mark that books, movies, and television bear – these outlets have a very small window of opportunity to grab their audience, if they miss that window it’s gone.  For me, ‘3079 – Block Action RPG’ missed that opportunity, and I really wish it hadn’t.
developer_response:
Thank you for the review, even if it is critical. However, I do want to make a few points:

If you restarted the game 12 times & only played a little over an hour, that is only ~5 minutes a run, which will make it hard to get into. I recommend players allow more time to grow.

Also, a strong story usually isn't a staple of games heavily inspired by roguelikes -- I didn't want to be bogged down in having to find a plausible explanation for things that just made the game work a little better. For example, scavengers or players that are having trouble getting items will be very happy to find items randomly dropped in buildings (they shouldn't be found outside).

Finally, you'll find in the screenshots section, many people enjoy the variety in characters, which is admittedly at times a bit silly & more importantly, fun.

Anyway, feel free to check out the sequel, 3089, which you may enjoy more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026782701', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 134, 'playtime_forever': 28, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28, 'last_played': 1385017809}
review:
Ok. So it looks like Minecraft in space, spawning a whole lot of U RIPD OFF MINECRAFT posts in the forums. It does look like minecraft. But it is nowhere near a rip off. Its not even remotely the same game. Now dont get me wrong, I love Minecraft and have owned it since late alpha. So another similar-looking game isnt bad in my book.
Now for the review.

As I said, it looks like Minecraft. Its a procedurally generated 3d block game, where the world/items are different every single time. So big 3d blocks with texures, prodecurally generated huge maps.

But thats where the similarities end. Its a space-RPG for starters. And all the quests and stuff are randomly generated, as far as the quest structure, it runs more like Daggerfall (without the horrid bugs). You meet a group of aliens, who give you random quests and rewards thereof. Enemies are "demons", really tought things that fly through the clouds. They are the main focus and plot of the game. There are also other alien races. You run around getting quests and items, fighting bad guys, and trying to stop the demon incursion. Simple, really. 

Its fun and totally worth 6-7$, especially if you like that style of graphics.
I just keep on trying to mine thru walls when I see a room I want to get to though...

author: {'steamid': '76561198059964384', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1388934141}
review:
Ein Action-RPG, angesiedelt in der fernen Zukunft. Der Spieler strandet auf einem hart umkämpften Planeten, wo er den freundlichen Humoids in ihrem Krieg gegen die Neanders und böse Dämonen zur Seite steht, sowohl zu Lande, als auch in der Luft. Die auf Voxel basierende Grafik ist stark von Minecraft inspiriert und dementsprechend besteht die Landschaft aus Blöcken und ist extrem verpixelt. Ebenso können manche Blöcke zerstört und neue Blöcke oder auch Fahrstühle und bewaffnete Türme mit dem entsprechenden Werkzeug gesetzt werden, allerdings nur in begrenztem Maß, ist das Werkzeug aufgebraucht muss ein neues her. Das Spielprinzip erinnert stark an Titel wie Borderlands: Es gilt dutzende Items zu sammeln, darunter verschiedene Arten von Schilden, Medikits und Radars sowie diverse Arten von Waffen, wobei manche wie bei Borderlands durch zusätzliche Effekte entweder mehr Schaden austeilen oder dem Spieler z.B. durch schnellere Energieaufladung helfen. Auch das Levelsystem erinnert an Borderlands. Die Waffen verbrauchen keine Munition, sondern Energie. Je stärker die Waffe, desto mehr Energie wird pro Schuss verbraucht. Ist der Energiebalken leer, muss einen Moment gewartet werden, bis er sich ausreichend aufgeladen hat. Dem kann der Spieler durch das Sammeln und Aktivieren von Generatoren und Batterien entgegenkommen. Seine Aufträge erhält der Spieler von den sogenannten "Leaders" der Humoids, welche mit einem Stern markiert sind. Überschüssige Items können bei den mit einem Dollar-Zeichen markierten "Merchants" gegen Credits, die Spielwährung, verkauft werden. So findet man sich ratzfatz in einem absoluten Sammelwahn wieder, immer auf der Jagd nach noch besseren und schlagkräftigeren Items.

FAZIT: Man erhält hier viel Spaß für wenig Geld und Festplattenplatz. Für Fans von Minecraft und (vorallem!) Borderlands ist dieser Titel definitiv einen Blick wert! Vorallem aber auch, weil es durch sein Oldschool-Spielprinzip und die verpixelte Grafik an die guten alten Zeiten erinnert, als ein Spieler nicht nur kurz in Deckung gehen musste, um sich zu erholen.
